citations.narrative:
The sheltered housing facility containing all dogs was 87.5 degrees Fahrenheit at 1:50 PM at the beginning of the
inspection (indicated by the inspectors kestrel). At 2:43 PM near the end of the inspection the facilities temperature was
87 degrees Fahrenheit (indicated by the facilities thermostat in the kennel). The facility representative stated that around 5
PM the temperature in the kennel was 86 degrees Fahrenheit and that the temperatures change in the facility based on
outside temperatures. According to weather archives the outdoor temperatures in the area were as follows: 12:51 PM 91
degrees Fahrenheit, 1:51 PM 91 degrees Fahrenheit, 2:51 PM 92 degrees Fahrenheit, 3:51 PM 90 degrees Fahrenheit,
4:51 PM 91 degrees Fahrenheit, 5:51 PM degrees Fahrenheit. Indicating that the temperature had been above 85
degrees Fahrenheit in the kennel for over 4 hours. The facility had fans attempting to cool the kennel and the dogs were
not showing signs of heat stress at the time of inspection. Temperatures that exceed 85 degrees Fahrenheit may cause
discomfort and possible heat related conditions to the dogs. The licensee must ensure that the ambient temperature not
fall below 45 °F (7.2 °C) for more than 4 consecutive hours when dogs or cats are present, and must not rise above 85 °F
(29.5 °C) for more than 4 consecutive hours when dogs or cats are present. Correct by 21-August-2025.

The facility has not had physical examinations performed on all dogs by the attending veterinarian in the past 12 months.
Three adult dogs at the facility (microchip numbers 2121, 4352, and 2353) have not had physical exams performed
annually as required. Failure to have each dog examined at least once a year can result in delay of treatment and
diagnosis for disease, illness, or injury. Correct by ensuring that a complete physical examination from head to tail of each
dog by the attending veterinarian is conducted not less than once every 12 months. Correct by 01-September-2025.

The facility has not administered vaccinations for distemper and parvo for two dogs (microchip numbers 2964 and 5510)
in the last year in accordance with the schedule outlined in the program of veterinary care. Additionally, fecal testing for
parasites and other pests have not been conducted in accordance with the program of veterinary care for the adult dogs.
Failure to follow a written and Attending Veterinarian approved schedule for vaccinations of contagious and/or deadly
diseases and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests can result in increased risk of disease exposure and
delay in treatment. The licensee must ensure that vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including
rabies, parvovirus and distemper) and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms,
coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian are administered.
Correct by, 25-August-2025.

The facility does not have adequate record of dates of administration for rabies vaccines in the adult dogs. The facility has
a note on the blank box of a calendar stating that the rabies vaccine was given this month. Additionally, there are no
additional records of vaccination administration for any female dogs that may have been whelping or pregnant during that
time that were required to receive the vaccine on a later date. Failure to maintain records of vaccines and treatments
administered to the dogs does not allow for APHIS officials to determine if the veterinarian approved vaccination schedule
is being followed. The facility must ensure that the names of all vaccines and treatments administered, and the dates of
administration are recorded. Correct by, 01-September-2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a Facility Representative.
